hints_html:
The graph of the linear approximation taken at \(a=1\) is the tangent line to the curve at \(a=1\).

The linear approximation to a function \(f\) at \(x=a\) is

\[\begin{aligned} L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a).\end{aligned}\]

sols_html:
We use the linear approximation of \(\ln(x)\) at \(x=1\) to estimate \(\ln(0.8)\). (Approximating at x = 1 is a logical choice, as 1 is close to 0.8, and we know that \(\ln(1) = 0\).)

We know \(\frac{d}{dx}\ln(x)=\frac1x\), which is equal to 1 when \(x=1\). Substituting this into the linear approximation formula, we get,

\[\begin{aligned} \ln(0.8)\approx \ln(1)+1(0.8-1) = 0-0.2=-0.2\end{aligned}\]
